description: Find out what help you can get to help you manage your debts.

details.body:
Find out what help you can get to manage your debts.

You’ll be asked questions about:

  • how much you owe
  • the things you own (such as property or a car)
  • help you’ve had with debts in the past

You do not have to give any personal information or financial details.

If you want to speak to someone about your debts you can get free, confidential and independent advice from a debt adviser.

nodes.body: The help you can get depends on what country you live in.
nodes.title: Where do you live?

nodes.body:
Your answer will only be used to show options relevant to you.

Include:

  • any loans you’ve been given, including money you owe to friends and family
  • credit card debts
  • any late bill payments (such as council tax or utility bills)
  • any late payments on your mortgage

Do not include:

  • regular mortgage repayments
  • student loans
  • budgeting loans
  • court fines
  • any child maintenance you owe
nodes.title: How much do you owe in total?

nodes.body:
Estimate what they’re worth now, not the amount you paid for them. A debt adviser will help you work out which assets can help pay off your debts.

Include items such as:

  • jewellery (not wedding rings)
  • high value electronic equipment such as games consoles or cameras
  • savings, shares, cryptocurrency
  • property

Do not include:

  • vehicles - you’ll be asked about these later
  • tools or equipment you use for work
  • your pension
  • items for your children (such as laptops used for school)
nodes.title: What's the total value of the things you own?

nodes.body:
This is the amount you think your vehicle is worth now, not the amount you paid for it.

Do not include any vehicles you’re still paying for. For example, through a hire purchase or a loan from a dealership.

A debt adviser can help you work out if your car can be used to help pay off your debts.
nodes.title: Do you own a vehicle outright that’s worth more than £2,000?

nodes.body:
If you’re not sure what arrangements you’ve had, speak to a free debt adviser.

The help you can get now depends on if you’ve had any of the following:

  • an Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA)
  • a Debt Relief Order (DRO)
  • a bankruptcy order

options.label: Yes, I have one of these now

nodes.title: Have you made arrangements to deal with your debts before?

nodes.body:
The rules for getting help with your debts are different if you live in Scotland. You can get help from:

  • Citizens Advice Scotland
  • Accountant in Bankruptcy (AiB)
  • Moneyhelper
nodes.title: If you live in Scotland

nodes.body:
The rules for getting help with your debts are different if you live in Northern Ireland. You can get help from:

  • Insolvency service Northern Ireland
  • Citizens Advice
  • MoneyHelper
nodes.title: If you live in Northern Ireland

nodes.body: You might be able to get help with your debts in the UK. Get free, confidential and independent advice from a debt adviser.
nodes.title: If you live outside the UK

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, these are the ways you can get help with your debts:

  • Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)
  • Debt Relief Order
  • Debt Management Plan

Get free, confidential and independent advice about these options from a debt adviser.

Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)

If you live in England or Wales, you can get temporary protection from the organisations you owe money to (your ‘creditors’) while you get debt advice and make a plan. This scheme is called Breathing Space.

You can get temporary protection for up to 60 days.

Cost

It’s free to use Breathing Space.

Debt Relief Order

A Debt Relief Order (DRO) is a way to deal with your debts if you:

  • owe £30,000 or less
  • cannot pay back the money you owe
  • do not own a house or have any spare income

A DRO usually lasts 12 months. During that time, you stop making payments towards the debts and your DRO is added to the Individual Insolvency Register.

At the end of the 12 months, you will not have to pay these debts anymore.

Your DRO is removed from the Insolvency Register 3 months after it ends. Your DRO will stay on your credit record for 6 years.

You need to apply for a DRO through a debt adviser.

Cost

You’ll need to pay a £90 administration fee. Some debt charities can help with this fee.

Debt Management Plan

A Debt Management Plan is an agreement between you and your creditors to pay all of your debts. It will stay on your credit record for 6 years.

Debt Management Plans are usually used when either:

  • you can only afford to pay creditors a small amount each month
  • you cannot make repayments now but will be able to make repayments in a few months

You can arrange a plan with your creditors yourself, through a charity or for a fee with a licensed debt management company.

Cost

It’s free to organise a Debt Management Plan yourself or through a charity. The cost varies if you use a debt management company.

Other ways to pay off your debts

You can also apply:

  • for an Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA)
  • to become bankrupt

Your options depend on the amount of money you owe and value of the things you own. A debt adviser will work out the best arrangement for you.
nodes.title: These are the ways you can get help dealing with your debts

nodes.body:
Based on your answers, these are the ways you can get help with your debts:

  • Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)
  • bankruptcy
  • Debt Management Plan
  • Individual Voluntary Arrangement

Get free, confidential and independent advice about these options from a debt adviser.

Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)

If you live in England or Wales, you can get temporary protection from the organisations you owe money to (your ‘creditors’). This gives you time to get debt advice and make a plan. This scheme is called Breathing Space.

You can get temporary protection for up to 60 days.

Cost

It’s free to use Breathing Space.

Bankruptcy

If you cannot pay off your debts, you can apply to become bankrupt.

Bankruptcy usually lasts 12 months. You’ll pay a fee when you apply and you’ll be released (‘discharged’) from most of your debts at the end.

Speak to a debt adviser before you apply for bankruptcy.

When you’re bankrupt:

  • you will not pay towards your debts, unless you can afford to

  • things you own (‘assets’) can be used to pay your debts

  • your creditors cannot contact you - an officer of the court (‘official receiver’) will deal with them for you

  • you’ll have bankruptcy restrictions around things like borrowing money and managing a business

Your bankruptcy will stay on your credit report for 6 years.

Your name and details will be published in the London Gazette and Insolvency Register.

Cost

You’ll need to pay a £680 administration fee.

Debt Management Plan

A Debt Management Plan is an agreement between you and your creditors to pay all of your debts.

Debt Management Plans are usually used when either:

  • you can only afford to pay creditors a small amount each month

  • you cannot make repayments now but will be able to make repayments in a few months

You can arrange a plan with your creditors yourself, through a charity or for a fee with a licensed debt management company.

Your Debt Management Plan will stay on your credit report for 6 years.

Cost

It’s free to organise a Debt Management Plan yourself or through a charity. The cost varies if you use a debt management company.

Individual Voluntary Arrangement

An Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA) is an agreement with your creditors to pay all or part of your debts. You agree to make regular payments to an insolvency practitioner, who will divide this money between your creditors.

Usually you’ll pay:

  • a setup fee
  • a handling fee each time you make a payment

Before you agree to an IVA, check with your insolvency practitioner how much of your payment will go towards paying off your debts.

Your IVA will stay on your credit report for 6 years.

Cost

This varies depending on your insolvency practitioner.
nodes.title: These are the ways you can get help dealing with your debts

nodes.body:
If you need help understanding your debts you can get free, confidential and independent advice from a debt adviser.

Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)

If you live in England or Wales, you can get temporary protection from the organisations you owe money to (your ‘creditors’). This gives you time to get debt advice and make a plan. This scheme is called Breathing Space.

You can get temporary protection for up to 60 days. It’s free to use Breathing Space.

Other options for dealing with your debts

A debt adviser can help you work out how to deal with your debts. They’ll ask you about the amount of money you owe and the value of the things you own.

You may be able to apply for:

  • a Debt Management Plan
  • an Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA)
  • a Debt Relief Order
  • bankruptcy
nodes.title: These are the ways you can get help dealing with your debts

nodes.body:
Get free advice from a debt adviser if you have one of the following and you’re in financial difficulty:

  • a Debt Relief Order (DRO)
  • a bankruptcy order
  • an Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA)
nodes.title: These are the ways you can get help dealing with your debts

nodes.body:
If you’ve had a previous debt arrangement, this can change the options available to you.

You can get free, confidential and independent advice about your options from a debt adviser.

Breathing Space (Debt Respite Scheme)

If you live in England or Wales, you can get temporary protection from the organisations you owe money to (your ‘creditors’). This gives you time to get debt advice and make a plan. This scheme is called Breathing Space.

You can get temporary protection for up to 60 days. It’s free to use Breathing Space.

Other options for dealing with your debts

A debt adviser can help you work out how to deal with your debts. They’ll ask you about the amount of money you owe and the value of the things you own.

You may be able to set up:

  • a Debt Management Plan
  • an Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA)

If you cannot pay off your debts you may be able to apply to become bankrupt.
